Officers were dispatched to the 4100 block of Nakoma Rd. shortly before 3 a.m.

People passing by called to report that a black sedan had crashed into a tree.

Officers arrived to find a man, smelling strongly of alcohol, sitting in the passenger seat.

A quick investigation indicated he was the driver of the vehicle.

Angel A. Gutierrez, 52, of Madison, was arrested for sixth-offense OWI.

He was medically cleared and taken to the Dane County Jail.

Multiple people called to report shots being fired on the east side Friday evening.

Officers were dispatched to the 100 block of Wittwer Rd. around 5:40 p.m.

They arrived to find two men fighting near a vehicle.

One of the men fired shots inside and outside of the vehicle.

The two men involved in this incident are known to one another.

Both men suffered minor injuries during the fight and were examined by EMS. No one was injured by a gunshot.

No nearby homes or vehicles were damaged by bullets.

Robert L. Gipson Jr., 23, of Fitchburg, was arrested for domestic disorderly conduct, first-degree recklessly endangering safety, being a felon in possession of a firearm and bail jumping charges.

The gun was recovered at the scene.

Detectives with the Violent Crime Unit responded to the scene.

Their investigation is ongoing at this time.

A man and woman were attacked during a home invasion Friday night on the city’s north side.

Officers were dispatched to the 2000 block of Northport Drive around 7:15 p.m.

Two men, armed with guns, entered the apartment and demanded money.
 
The victims were pistol-whipped as the suspects ransacked the apartment. The male victim was also tied up during the incident.

The suspects stole various electronics from the home.

Officers are reviewing digital evidence.

Anyone with information about this incident is asked to contact Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014 or online at p3tips.com.

This remains an active investigation.

A woman, who was being followed by another driver, drove to our Midtown Police District to seek help Saturday night.

The victim first encountered the other driver near Cypress Way on the south side of the city.

The suspect then followed her to the parking lot of the Midtown District.

While in the parking lot, the suspect made a throat-slitting motion toward the victim. She drove away as officers approached.

Officers nearby attempted to stop her vehicle, but she continued to speed away.

Another law enforcement agency eventually made contact with the suspect during a crash investigation in their jurisdiction.

Probable cause has been drafted for disorderly conduct and eluding.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

A woman was able to run away and call for help after a man assaulted her in the stairway of her apartment building.

Officers were dispatched to an apartment building located along the 700 block of University Ave. around 5 p.m. Saturday.

The victim said the man assaulted her and made threatening comments as she passed by him in the stairwell.

The victim was able to fight away from his grasp.

The University of Wisconsin Police Department worked with MPD officers to locate the suspect in a nearby construction area.

Officers formed a perimeter and took the suspect into custody.

Michael J. Condron, 25, of Madison, was arrested for fourth-degree sexual assault.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

A man threatened to harm law enforcement officers after he was arrested for punching a mall security guard.

Officers were dispatched to East Towne Mall around 2:30 p.m. Saturday.

The suspect was causing a disturbance at the mall and was asked to leave the property.

While being escorted out, the man punched and spit in the face of the security guard.


Officers located the suspect nearby. He became combative as he was being placed under arrest.

The suspect also attempted to damage a squad car.

The suspect threatened to kill the officers taking him to the hospital.

After he was medically cleared, Yahyaa N. Kelly, 47, was arrested for disorderly conduct, threats to law enforcement officers, discharging bodily fluids at law enforcement officers, resisting arrest and bail jumping.

Multiple people, including a nearby officer, reported hearing shots fired Sunday night on the city’s west side.

Officers were dispatched to the 1100 block of Morraine View Dr. around 9:45 p.m.

Officers checked the area and found five shell casings. No property damage was located.

No injuries were reported.

Anyone with information about this incident is asked to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014. Tips can also be submitted online at p3tips.com.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

The Madison Police Department is investigating a shooting on the city’s west side.

Officers were dispatched to the 7900 block of Tree Lane around 10:50 a.m.

This remains a very active scene.

More information will be released later.

Madison Police responded to the area of Gene Parks Pl, Mike McKinney Ct and Allied Dr on multiple reports of shots fired in the neighborhood.

Officers discovered that two doors from separate buildings were struck by gunfire.  There are no reports of injuries, however, both buildings were occupied at the time of the shooting.  A total of ten (10) fired cartridge casings have been recovered from the roadway.

If you have any information regarding this incident, please contact the Madison Police Department at 608-255-2345.  If you wish to remain anonymous, please contact Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014, or, on the web at p3tips.com.  Individuals contacting Crime Stoppers can receive up to $1,000 in cash rewards for tips that lead to an arrest.

Madison Police are currently assisting Madison Fire Department with a large structure fire resulting in closure of Park Street.  The fire may possibly involve potentially hazardous material.  Residents in that area should remain indoors, all persons/motorists should avoid the area until the risk can be assessed and the situation is contained.

MPD Officers were dispatched to a disturbance in the 10 block of Schroeder Ct. Upon arrival, officers located a female and male inside the building. Both parties appeared to have sustained injuries as the result of a domestic altercation and were transported to area hospitals.
 
Parties involved know each other and there is no ongoing threat to the public. The investigation is active and being led by MPD’s Violent Crime Unit. If anyone has information on this incident, please contact Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 266-6014, or, on the web at P3Tips.com

During the month of April, the Madison Police Department, in partnership with the Dane County Sheriff's Office, will be conducting extra patrols that will focus on enforcing Wisconsin's alcohol and seatbelt laws.  These additional enforcement efforts are made possible through traffic overtime grants provided by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation. 

The goal of these extra patrols is not only to enhance public safety, but to prevent needless tragedies.  Someone is injured or killed in an impaired driving crash every two hours in Wisconsin and thousands of unbuckled passenger vehicle occupants are killed every year in crashes throughout the United States.

The Madison Police Department needs your help to make our roads safer in 2023.  Please put your cell phone down, buckle up, slow down and drive sober.  If you have been drinking, please call a sober friend, a cab or a ride-share service to get you home safely.

Multiple people reported hearing shots fired Saturday morning on the city's south side.

Officers responded to the 2200 block of Luann Lane around 4:10 a.m.

No injuries or property damage were reported.

Several shell casings were located on the sidewalk.

Anyone with information about this incident is asked to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014. Tips can also be submitted online at p3tips.com.

The investigation is ongoing.

Address: John Nolen Dr. at E. Wilson St.
Details:
Two people were injured after a drunk driver crashed into their vehicle.

Officers were dispatched to the intersection of John Nolen Dr. and E. Wilson St. around 12:45 a.m. on Saturday.

A driver was headed into oncoming traffic when he struck another vehicle.

Two people in the other vehicle were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

Thomas T. Vu, 34, was arrested for OWI causing injury.

A woman attacked an eye clinic employee after she found out her prescription wouldn’t be ready that day.

Officers were dispatched to the 4300 block of E. Washington Ave. around 12:20 p.m. on Saturday.

The suspect threw the victim up against a wall. The victim suffered minor injuries.

Another store employee was also assaulted.

The suspect left before officers arrived at the clinic. 

Probable cause was developed to arrest the suspect for simple battery and disorderly conduct.

No arrests have been made.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

Officers are investigating after someone attempted to steal pills from a pharmacy on the city’s north side.

Around 9:15 p.m. Saturday, officers were dispatched to a store located along the 3700 block of E. Washington Ave.

A man jumped over the pharmacy counter and indicated he had a weapon on him. He then demanded prescription pills from the pharmacist and pharmacist techs.

The suspect ran out of the store without taking anything.

No one was physically injured during this incident.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

Address: S. Park St. at Planert Dr.
Details:
A victim reported having a gun flashed at him during a road rage incident Saturday night on the city's south side. 

The victim was driving his vehicle near S. Park St. and Planert Dr. around 11 p.m. when those inside a red Nissan Sentra became frustrated with his driving behavior. 

While at a stop sign, the victim said the driver and a passenger in the red car approached him and began making profane gestures. 

The victim also observed the driver flash what appeared to be a gun. He was not physically injured.

He was able to call for help. 

The suspects left the area prior to police arrival.

No arrests have been made.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

Address: E. Washington Ave. at Fair Oaks Ave.
Details:
Several people suffered minor injuries during a three-vehicle crash on the eastside Saturday afternoon.

Officers were dispatched to E. Washington Ave. at Fair Oaks Ave. shortly before 2 p.m.

A driver crashed into a pickup truck, which then crashed into a third vehicle.

Two people in the first car were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The 19-year-old driver of this vehicle showed no signs of impairment. 

He was cited for failure to control a vehicle and other traffic violations.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

Hotel staff called police to report a man was inside their lobby carrying a knife.

Officers were dispatched to the 400 block of W. Johnson St. around 6:45 p.m. Sunday.

No knife was located on the suspect. He became resistive and began spitting at the officers taking him into custody.

Hamzah B. Holley, 21, was arrested for disorderly conduct, throwing or discharging bodily fluids at public safety workers and bail jumping.

A man, who injured himself attempting to break into a business, was found minutes afterward with a fresh cut on his hand.

Officers were initially dispatched to a jewelry store, located along the 4100 block of E. Washington Ave., Thursday night for a tripped alarm.

They arrived to find the front door of a commercial building smashed. A door to a jewelry store was also damaged.

Hours later, an employee was inside the store when the burglary suspect returned. He once again tried to break down the door.

Officers were nearby and observed the suspect leaving the area. They found him bleeding from attempting to break the door.

Dane A. Killerlain, 58, was arrested for two counts of attempted burglary and criminal damage to property.

A woman threw a ball of mud, made from her own spit, at officers responding to a domestic disturbance in which she was involved.

Officers were dispatched to an apartment along the 1700 block of Fordem Ave. shortly before 6 a.m. on Sunday.

A man told officers the suspect was threatening him and pulled a fire alarm in the building.

The suspect was arrested for domestic disorderly conduct, discharging bodily fluids and false fire activation after mental health crisis workers were notified.

The investigation is ongoing.

A woman called police after finding what appeared to be a bullethole inside her condo.

Officers were dispatched to Oak Creek Trail shortly before noon on Friday.

The woman first noticed a hole in the exterior wall of her unit. She then observed more damage in an interior wall.

Officers located more than a dozen shell casings in the road directly across the street. This shots-fired incident occurred sometime overnight.

No injuries were reported.

No arrests have been made.

Anyone with information is asked to contact Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014 or online at p3tips.com.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

A drunk driver was arrested after he backed into a sign and then fell asleep inside his running vehicle.

Offices were dispatched to a brewery located along the 600 block of Whitney Way around 9:50 p.m. Tuesday.

The driver's blood alcohol limit was three times over the legal limit in Wisconsin.

Collin A. Clark, 31, was arrested for first-offense OWI.

Two people, found sleeping in a stolen car, deliberately crashed into a law enforcement vehicle in an attempt to escape from police.

An MPD officer was asked to check on a suspicious vehicle parked along the 1600 block of Wyoming Way on Tuesday morning.

Officers deflated the vehicle's tires and awaked the suspects. The suspects drove into multiple squad cars as they attempted to speed away.

The vehicle eventually crashed along N. Sherman Ave. 
A 14-year-old male then ran from the vehicle.  Officers followed him over fences and through backyards before taking him into custody.

He was arrested on several charges including second-degree recklessly endangering safety and eluding officers. He was taken to the Juvenile Reception Center. He also has had multiple pas police contacts and was wanted on a capias warrant. 

David A. Wills, 18, of Madison, remained in the vehicle and was arrested for operating and motor vehicle without an owner's consent. He has also had multiple past police contacts and is a suspect in multiple burglaries throughout Dane County. 

Two loaded handguns were found inside the vehicle. One of the firearms had been reported stolen. 

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

One person reported hearing multiple gunshots on the northside late Tuesday night.

Officers were dispatched to the 1400 block of Trailsway shortly before 10 p.m.

No other people reported hearing gunshots.

No injuries were reported and there were no signs of a shooting.

No damages or casings were located when officers checked the area.

Address: E. Washington Ave. at N. Paterson St.
Details:
A stolen handgun was recovered during a traffic stop involving an impaired driver.

Officers pulled someone over at the intersection of E. Washington Ave. and N. Paterson St. around 12:15 a.m. on Wednesday.

A driver showed signs of impairment and admitted to smoking marijuana and drinking alcohol before driving.

A search of the vehicle located a stolen gun under a floor mat.

Tyree D. Brock-Tolbert, 33, was arrested for third-offense OWI, being a felon in possession of a gun, possessing a stolen gun and going armed while intoxicated.

He is currently out on a signature bond for being a felon in possession of a firearm for a different agency's case.

Missing from the North Side of Madison is a Patricia Sawyer-Kane. Patricia is a white female, 84 years of age with shoulder length white hair. Patricia was last seen wearing a dark green North Face jacket, a white shirt, and black jeans. Patricia has dementia. Patricia was last seen on foot. If located please contact the Dane County 911 Center.

MPD responded to the 300 block of W Gorham St at 1:42am for a reported weapon's offense. Officers discovered one victim who had sustained wounds from a gunshot. That victim was transported to a local area hospital for treatment. A subject associated with this incident was detained. There are no further concerns that the public is at risk related to this incident. The investigation is on-going.

Address: E. Washington Ave. at N. Blair St.
Details:
An impaired driver crashed into a vehicle which collided into a third car during a crash Sunday night.

Officers were dispatched to the intersection of E. Washington Ave. at N. Blair St. around 8:30 p.m. 

Edward Barrera, 25, was cited for first-offense OWI and other traffic citations.

Two officers were injured late Monday night while responding to a disturbance on the east side.

Officers were dispatched to the 200 block of Demilo Way around 11:30 p.m.

A man had trapped a woman inside a room and assaulted her.

He then fought with two other men at the home.

The suspect continued to fight for an extended time after officers arrived on scene.

Two officers suffered minor injuries while taking the man into custody.

David Harris, 41, was arrested for false imprisonment, substantial battery, attempted third-degree sexual assault, battery, disorderly conduct and resisting arrest causing soft tissue damage.

A man wanted on several felony warrants involving weapons and firearms investigations attempted to run over a group of officers assisting with his arrest.

The incident happened Thursday afternoon on Stewart St.

Members of the Gang and Neighborhood Crime Abatement Team, Special Weapons and Tactics team and Safe Streets Task Force were working together to take Sorrell A. Gilmore,28, into custody.

After driving toward officers, Gilmore sped away from the area.

Officers used tire deflation devices to stop his vehicle. He was taken into custody at the intersection of Dane and Taft Streets.

Gilmore was arrested for fleeing and eluding, being in possession of cocaine, possessing a controlled substance, possessing THC and his outstanding warrants.

He was taken to the Dane County Jail.

No officers of community members were injured during Thursday’s incident.

Two young children were left in a running vehicle, parked illegally, outside of a mall Monday afternoon.

Officers were dispatched to the Food Court area of East Towne Mall around 4:30 p.m.

Officers arrived to find the children drenched in sweat, since the temperature inside the vehicle was warmer than that of outside.

EMS examined both kids and determined hospitalization was not necessary.

Child Protective Services was contacted.

Myberling Jeaneth Moreno Martinez, 28, was arrested for child neglect and taken to the Dane County Jail.

The investigation is ongoing.

A man was arrested after getting physical with bar staff and exposing himself to customers.

Officers were dispatched to a bar located along the 100 block of King St. around 11:50 p.m. Monday.

Lance Kilcoyne, 36, was arrested for obstructing, disorderly conduct, lewd and lascivious behavior, resisting arrest and trespassing.

The investigation is ongoing.

An officer heard several gun shots early Friday morning during a patrol on the north side.

The shots sounded as if they were coming from the Trailsway and Brentwood Pkwy area.

An off-duty officer also reported hearing gunshots.

No injuries were reported.

Officers checked this area but were unable to find a scene or signs of property damage.

Anyone with information about this incident is asked to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014. Tips can also be submitted online at p3tips.com.

Officers were unable to find any signs of a shooting following reports of shots being fired on the east side.

Officers were dispatched to the 4500 block of Stein Ave. around 11:30 p.m.
 
The area was checked and no damage or casings were located.

No injuries were reported.

Anyone with information about this incident is asked to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014. Tips can also be submitted online at p3tips.com.

A woman was filling her car up with gas when a stray bullet broke through her back window.

Officers were dispatched to the BP gas station located along the 4300 block of Britta Parkway around 10:30 p.m. Thursday.
 
More than 10 people called to report hearing shots fired all across the Dunn Marsh Neighborhood, including an off-duty MPD sergeant.
 
Officers multiple shell casings in the green space between Britta Dr. and Britta Pkwy.

No one was injured.

Officers spent Thursday night canvassing the neighborhood and reviewing digital evidence.
 
No arrests have been made.

Anyone with information about this incident is asked to contact Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014 or online at p3tips.com.
On 4/16/23 at approximately 3:30 PM, MPD located two individuals deceased inside a residence in the 2800 block of Moland Street. Investigation is on-going. This is an isolated incident.

A woman accidentally drove into a porch Monday afternoon.

Officers responded to the 3800 block of Eliot Ln. around 1:55 p.m.

The woman said she accidentally put the vehicle into drive instead of reverse.

She was not injured but was taken to the hospital as a precaution.

One person was arrested for attempting to break into a dollar store on the city's west side.

Officers were dispatched to the 700 block of Gammon Rd. around 2:50 a.m. on Monday.

They arrived to find the suspect near the building.

The suspect also had burglarious tools on him when he was located.

A store door was damaged during this incident.

Jayson J. Toussaint, 22, was arrested for attempted burglary, criminal damage to property, possessing burglary tools and resisting arrest.

A man was arrested after breaking into an apartment and threatening those inside.

Officers were dispatched to the 1100 block of Macarthur Rd. around 3:27 a.m. Tuesday.

The suspect broke several glass items while inside.

Several roommates pinned him down until officers arrived.

One person was injured during this incident.

Giovanni J. Vasquez-Rivera, 30, was arrested for burglary, disorderly conduct, battery and possession of drug paraphernalia.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

A man was attempting to sell shoes via a social media site when someone flashed a gun and robbed him during the transaction.

Officers were dispatched to the 100 block of Kennedy Heights around 1:30 a.m. Sunday.

The victim said the buyer and another man showed up at their designated meeting spot. The other man flashed a gun when it came time to pay.

The seller was not injured during this incident.

No arrests have been made.

Anyone with information about this incident is asked to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014 or online at p3tips.com.

The Madison Police Department has a list of ways you can stay safe while buying or selling something online.

The Madison Police Department is investigating after two vehicles, a purse and wallet were stolen during a residential burglary.

Officers were dispatched to the 7900 block of W. Oakbrook Circle around 7:30 a.m. Saturday.

The suspects likely gained entry to the home by using a garage door opener left inside a vehicle.

No one was injured during this incident.

No arrests have been made.

The investigation is ongoing.

The Madison Police Department is investigating after keys, a purse and a vehicle were stolen during a residential burglary.

The suspects made entry to the house through an open garage door.

No one was injured.

No arrests have been made.

The incident remains under investigation.

A Madison man was arrested for multiple drug charges after crashing a vehicle into a light pole on the city’s east side.

On April 6, officers were contacted about a man passed out in a suspicious vehicle parked in the area of Nakoosa Trail and Brandie Rd. The vehicle ended up being stolen out of Milwaukee.

The man fought with officers as they responded. Officers were able to apply a handcuff to his wrist, before he managed to drive away, striking a squad car in the process.
 
The same man was the suspect in a drug investigation case through the Dane County Narcotics Task Force.
 
Task Force detectives and MPD officers worked together to locate the suspect, who was riding in a car traveling on Highway 51.

Around 10:15 a.m., MPD officers initiated a traffic stop at the intersection of S. Stoughton and Buckeye roads. The car initially stopped, but attempted to flee and ultimately crashed into a traffic pole.

Officers arrested Antonio Fernandez, 22, of Madison, for first-degree recklessly endangering safety, second-degree recklessly endangering safety, operating a motor vehicle without an owner’s consent, felony bail jumping, resisting arrest, manufacture with intent to deliver fentanyl and manufacture to deliver cocaine.
 
Fernandez was taken to the Dane County Jail.
 
The investigation is ongoing at this time.

Two stray bullets entered an occupied apartment during a shots fired incident Sunday evening.

Officers were dispatched to the 2900 block of Coho St. around 5:30 p.m.

Multiple people reported hearing the shots.

Several shell casings were located in the street. 

Two rounds were found lodged inside an apartment. A woman and child were home at the time of the shooting. Thankfully neither were injured.

No arrests have been made. 

Anyone with information about this incident is asked to contact Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014 or online at p3tips.com.

The incident remains under investigation.

Arrested:
Marquon T. Webb, 19
Cecelia T. Goldsberry, 21
Keyonte M. Barksdale, 20
Tommy L. Nicks, 17
Details:
Multiple agencies worked together during a shots-fired investigation on Madison’s east side early Tuesday morning.

A caller reported that another vehicle shot at him as he drove in the area of Acewood Boulevard and Goldfinch Dr.

Madison officers engaged in a short pursuit of the suspect’s vehicle, and Monona Police Department picked up the pursuit.

Madison officers were able to spike and disable the vehicle on southbound Highway 151. Five people inside ran away from the vehicle.

Three suspects were quickly caught.

An MPD drone went up and quickly located another suspect walking near a wooded area. A still image from the drone search is included in this release.

A Monona K-9 team was able to take this suspect into custody.

Two guns, including one that was stolen, were located near the vehicle.

The vehicle the suspects were driving was also listed as stolen.

Marquon T. Webb, 19, Cecelia T. Goldsberry, 21, Keyonte M. Barksdale, 20, and Tommy L. Nicks, 17, were all arrested on a myriad of charges and outstanding warrants.

The investigation is ongoing.

Address: Mineral Point Rd. at D'onofrio Dr.
Details:
A driver suffered serious injuries after a stolen vehicle crashed into her car.

The crash happened Saturday afternoon in the area of Mineral Point Road and D’onofrio Dr.

Those inside the stolen vehicle ran from the scene. A stolen firearm was also located inside the vehicle.

The victim was taken to the hospital. She is expected to survive.

No arrests have been made at this time.

Anyone with information about this incident is encouraged to contact Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014 or online at p3tips.com.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

An officer observed a man speeding and driving recklessly minutes before he crashed into a house on Madison’s west side.

The officer was on a routine patrol on Country Grove Drive around 12:45 p.m. Tuesday when this occurred.

The driver saw him and tried speeding away. He then crashed into a home along the 7300 block of Arctic Fox Dr.

The driver told the responding officer he was being chased by a person with a gun. No other vehicles were observed in the area by the officer. 

The driver was taken to a local hospital for minor injuries.

He was left in the care of his family and issued driving citations.

No one inside the home was injured.

The Madison Fire Department was called to check on the structural damage to the home.

The Madison Police Department is investigating after a man showed up at the hospital with stab wounds.

Officers checked his home on Odana Ln. to see if there were any other victims. None were located.

The man’s injuries are not considered life-threatening.

No arrests have been made.

This remains an active investigation.

The Madison Police Department responded to a large fight between students from LaFollette High School and other schools in Dane County.

Officers were dispatched to the 700 block of Pflaum Rd. around 11:30 a.m. Tuesday.

The students ran from the area when officers arrived. It’s unclear how many were involved.

Two students were given a restorative justice referral.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

Address: Milwaukee St / S Fair Oaks Ave
Details:
At approximately 5:06 PM, a Madison Police officer spotted a vehicle believed to be involved in an earlier traffic incident where an unknown male occupant had threatened to shoot someone in another vehicle.  This suspect vehicle was stopped by officers as it pulled into a gas station parking lot near the intersection of Milwaukee St and S Fair Oaks Ave.  This contact and investigation was performed without incident.
 
As this investigation was unfolding, another officer saw an unrelated vehicle parked in this same lot, occupied by a male who had outstanding probable cause for his arrest.  A team of officers initiated contact with this second vehicle.  The wanted male occupant refused to comply with multiple lawful orders to exit.  Police forced entry into the vehicle and took this suspect into custody without incident.  He was taken to the Dane County Jail on tentative charges of Disorderly Conduct, Resisting an Officer and Possession of Cocaine.
 
As these two investigations were coming to a close, officers were flagged down by the owner of a third vehicle who had accidentally locked their keys in their car.  A patrol officer broke away from one of the ongoing investigations to assist this vehicle owner and provide resources to get the car unlocked on scene.

In the early morning hours of 3-3-23, Madison Police Officers responded to the 3900 block of Dempsey Road for a Non-Residential Burglary.  Upon arrival, officers were contacted by the manager of the business, who reported that a suspect had broken into the business and stole keys to a vehicle on the lot.  The suspect began to drive the stolen vehicle into other vehicles in attempt to get out of the lot, causing thousands of dollars of damage to vehicles and property.  The suspect fled the scene in the stolen vehicle.  Officers and Investigators processed the crime scene for evidence. 

Detectives from the Burglary Crime Unit began to work the case and the stolen auto was recovered.  It was processed for evidence and released.  BCU Detectives obtained video from numerous sources and processed forensic evidence.

On 4-20-23, BCU Detectives arrested Paul J Ascher and charged him with Burglary, Take and Operate a Motor Vehicle Without Owner’s Consent, and multiple counts of Criminal Damage to Property.  Ascher was out on bail for felony cases at the time of this crime and was also charged with counts of Felony Bail Jumping.

Madison Police Officers were sent to 201 S. Gammon Road, Memorial High School, in reference to a Weapons Complaint.  Information was given that a person was armed with a handgun.  MPD made contact with a 16 year old student that was in possession of a loaded handgun.  Officers were able to safely take possession of the firearm.  The juvenile was taken to the Juvenile Reception Center and charged with Possession of a Firearm on School Property.  MMSD is aware of the incident and cooperating with MPD's investigation.

A stolen handgun was recovered during an arrest made at this year’s Mifflin Street Block Party.

Officers spent hours Saturday walking and biking in the area.
 
Students arrived to Mifflin Street around 11 a.m. By midday, the crowd surged to well over 10,000 people. In response, the Madison Police Department shutdown Mifflin Street and other nearby roads to traffic.

Dozens arrested

As of 6 p.m. Saturday, 44 people had been arrested. Most were arrested for alcohol related offenses. Additional arrests are possible.

Three people were taken to the Dane County Jail, including an adult male who had a stolen gun in his backpack.

More information about these arrests will be released on Monday.

Team effort

Around 200 officers worked the event.

A number of units within the Madison Police Department, including our Special Events Team, Mounted Patrol Unit, Unmanned Aircraft System team, Special Weapons and Tactics team, along with district leadership and patrol officers assisted in keeping attendees safe.

The Madison Police Department would like to thank the Dane County Sheriff’s Office, UW-Madison Police, Capitol Police, the Madison Fire Department and Building Inspection for their help.

The Mifflin Street Block Party is typically held the final Saturday in April. It is not a University-sponsored event, nor is it a sanctioned event by the city.

At approximately 1:57am, Madison Police Officers were notified that a 15-year-old male had been dropped off at UW Health East Madison (4602 Eastpark Boulevard) having sustained a gunshot wound(s). Madison Police Officers, a Sergeant, and Investigator quickly responded to the hospital. Officers were able to make brief contact with the victim before he was transferred to a different hospital via med flight. He is currently in stable condition.

Detectives from the Violent Crime Unit (VCU) are in to assist with the investigation. Anyone with information regarding this incident should call Madison Police at 608-255-2345. Anonymous tips can also be submitted through the Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014 or online at p3tips.com.

Early Tuesday morning, officers checked on a woman screaming near a storage facility on Verona Road.

Officers arrived to find no on-going disturbance, but recognized the woman involved. She had an outstanding warrant for battery to law enforcement officers.

She resisted arrest as she was being taken into custody. Officers also found personal documents belonging to someone else and several concealed knifes on her.

Jessica A. Leroy, 36, was arrested for resisting arrest, theft, felon in possession of a concealed knife, the outstanding warrant and bail jumping.

The investigation is ongoing at this time.

On 5/5/2023 at approximately 12:15 AM, Madison Police officers were dispatched to a weapons violation in the 1600 block of Seminole Highway.  Madison Police personnel are continuing to investigate and there is not believed to be a threat to the public.

Arrested:
Blake A. Bjork, 23
Scott G. Novak, 22
Details:
Two men were arrested for causing a disturbance and yelling racial slurs at a man walking by.

The Madison Police Department will be joining police departments across Wisconsin and the United States in stepping up the enforcement of seatbelt laws. The high-visibility Click It or Ticket seatbelt campaign, which coincides with the beginning of the busy summer travel season, runs from May 22 through June 4, 2023. 

The purpose of the campaign is to remind motorists about the importance of seatbelt use, enforce the life-saving habit of wearing a seatbelt and reduce the number of fatalities that occur when drivers and passengers fail to buckle up.  Wisconsin’s primary seatbelt law allows law enforcement to stop and cite motorists for failing to wear a seatbelt. Drivers can also be cited for every unbuckled passenger in their vehicle.

Not wearing a seatbelt can have tragic consequences.  Drivers and passengers who do not wear their seatbelt, are 80 times more likely to be ejected from the vehicle in a crash and eight times more likely to die in a crash.  Wearing your seatbelt is one of the easiest and most effective steps you can take to survive a crash.  Unfortunately, Wisconsin’s seatbelt use is dropping and failure to fasten a seatbelt is among the most common traffic violations in Wisconsin.  

The Madison Police Department and the Wisconsin Department of Transportation are asking for your help with making our roads safer and achieving zero traffic-related deaths in Wisconsin. 

Please buckle up.  Every trip.  Every time.

The Madison Police Department to Participate in a State-Funded Bicycle and Pedestrian Safety Grant from June 2023 to August 2023
 
This summer, the Madison Police Department will be conducting extra patrols that will focus on enforcing Wisconsin’s bicycle and pedestrian laws.  These additional enforcement efforts are made possible through traffic overtime grants provided by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation.

The goal of these extra patrols is not only to enhance public safety, but to also educate citizens and to prevent needless tragedies. Throughout the past five years in Wisconsin, there have been 10,737 pedestrians and bicyclists crashes, resulting in 9799 injuries and 336 deaths.  In 2022 alone, 1,378 pedestrians and 679 bicyclists in Wisconsin were involved in motor vehicle crashes, resulting in 74 and 14 deaths, respectively. 
  • Bicycles, according to WI Statute, are considered vehicles. They have the same rights on the roadways as motor vehicles and they must obey the rules of the road like any other vehicle.
  • Motorists should leave at least three feet when passing bicycles, more room at higher speeds.  They should change lanes to pass any bicycle traveling, if possible.
  • Motorists should look for bicycles in the opposing lane to them before they turn left.  The most common cause of bicycle crashes is a motorist making a left turn across the path of an oncoming bicycle.
  • Motorists should scan sidewalks and crosswalks for pedestrians and bicyclists.  They must yield to pedestrians who have started crossing at an intersection or crosswalk.  Motorists must also yield to pedestrians who have started crossing a roadway, within a marked or an unmarked crosswalk, at an intersection not controlled by traffic signals.
  • Motorists should always look for bicyclists and pedestrians to their right side before they leave a stop light or stop sign. They should also look to the left and right side sidewalks when they are on a one-way street.
  • Pedestrians should not suddenly move into the path of a closely approaching vehicle that does not have sufficient time to yield for them.
The Madison Police Department needs your help to make our roads safer for EVERYONE.  Distracted driving, walking or biking can cause grave danger to you and anyone else on the road.  Please obey all traffic laws, focus on the road, be aware of others and pay attention to your surroundings and potential dangers when you are driving, biking or walking.

The Madison Police Department found no signs of explosives at La Follette High School after a threatening email was sent to staff members.

Several staff received an anonymous email mentioning a bomb threat and other acts of violence toward the school.

Officers were dispatched to the building around 11 a.m. Thursday.

An MPD K-9 team conducted a search of lockers and school grounds and no explosives were found.

A 16-year-old male was arrested for terrorists threats (party to a crime) for the incident. He was taken to the Juvenile Reception Center.

The Madison Metropolitan School District sent a letter home to La Follette families about this incident.

School leaders, per guidance from MPD, activated its Safety Response Protocol and put the building in a “secure” status, meaning no one was permitted to enter or exit the building. A “hold” was also activated, which meant staff and students remained in their classrooms.

MMSD and MPD continue to work together in this investigation.

Watch Your Speed!

This summer, the Madison Police Department, in partnership with the Dane County Sheriff's Office, will be conducting extra patrols that will focus on enforcing Wisconsin's speeding laws. Speeding is a leading cause of death and injuries on Wisconsin roadways. Speeding puts drivers, their passengers and everyone else on the road at a greater risk of a serious crash. 

We will also be continuing our efforts to enforce Wisconsin's alcohol and seatbelt laws. Someone is injured or killed in an impaired driving crash every two hours in Wisconsin and thousands of unbuckled passenger vehicle occupants are killed every year in crashes throughout the United States.

These additional enforcement efforts are made possible through traffic overtime grants provided by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation. The goal of these extra patrols is not only to enhance public safety, but to prevent needless tragedies. 

The Madison Police Department needs your help to make our roads safer.  Please put your cell phone down, buckle up, slow down and drive sober.

During the past two months, officers with the Madison Police Department have responded to a number of burglaries at storage unit properties in the city.

Suspects in these incidents have cut off locks, forced entry into units, or gained entry to them by climbing through walls and ceilings. 

Clothes, bicycles, tools, jewelry, photographs and family records have been stolen.

One incident occured May 27 at Aberg Mini Warehouses. Staff watched as a man was trying to break into several units. Troy Lorenz was arrested in this case. Officers are investigating additional cases he may be involved in.

Other charges and arrests are possible. 

The Madison Police Department's Burglary Crime Unit recommends people check rented storage units often, safeguard any keys or passes for their units and keep an inventory of items stored inside.

Officers also suggest writing down serial numbers of electronics, appliances, tools and vehicles stored inside your unit.

The Madison Police Department and the family of Kelly Nolan continue to search for information surrounding her death, 16 years after she was reported missing. 

The Nolan family is offering a $25,000 reward for any information that could lead to the conviction of her killer.

Kelly was last seen in downtown Madison during the early morning hours of June 23, 2007. Her body was found 16 days later, on July 9, in a wooded property along the 4700 block of Schneider Dr. in the town of Dunn.

Kelly was a 22-year-old UW-Whitewater student living in Madison for the summer. She was subletting an apartment on East Mifflin Street and searching for a part-time job.

She spent the night before her disappearance out with friends. They eventually separated and Kelly remained in the State Street area. Witness accounts place her along the 500 block of State St. between 2:20 and 2:30 a.m. on that Saturday.

Multiple veteran detectives remain assigned to this case. They continue to pursue all new leads and remain committed to finding the person or persons responsible.

They are still working to determine who may have been involved in Kelly's death and whether she left the downtown area on her own accord or forcibly.

No one is currently considered a person of interest or suspect.

Kelly was wearing an emerald green, scooped-necked shirt and jeans. She was carrying a grayish-green handbag with several outside pockets.

If you remember seeing her downtown that night or have any information regarding this case, please contact police.

All tips are investigated thoroughly. No piece of information or detail is considered too small or too insignificant. It may be what is needed for detectives to solve this case.

Information can be submitted by contacting the Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014 or online at p3tips.com.

Tips can be submitted anonymously, and people may be eligible for an additional cash reward through Crime Stoppers.

Below is a statement the Nolan family has asked the Madison Police Department to release on their behalf.

“We miss her every day. Kelly’s death changed our family, but her legacy of love and kindness keeps us going. She was a daughter, sister, niece and friend. Someone with contagious energy who could always make us laugh. The type of person who sought the good in this world. She was just beginning to live her life when she was tragically taken from us. Someone out there knows something. We know coming forward will not be easy. But we ask you to tell police what you heard, saw or believe happened to Kelly. Help our family understand what happened to Kelly during her final moments. We want to thank the Madison Police Department, which remains dedicated to solving this case and works daily to prevent other innocent young women from becoming victims.”

The family of Kelly Nolan

The Madison Police Department to Participate in a State-Funded Bicycle and Pedestrian Safety Grant from June 2023 to August 2023
 
This summer, the Madison Police Department will be conducting extra patrols that will focus on enforcing Wisconsin’s bicycle and pedestrian laws.  These additional enforcement efforts are made possible through traffic overtime grants provided by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation.

The goal of these extra patrols is not only to enhance public safety, but to also educate citizens and to prevent needless tragedies. Throughout the past five years in Wisconsin, there have been 10,737 pedestrians and bicyclists crashes, resulting in 9799 injuries and 336 deaths.  In 2022 alone, 1,378 pedestrians and 679 bicyclists in Wisconsin were involved in motor vehicle crashes, resulting in 74 and 14 deaths, respectively. 

Bicycles, according to WI Statute, are considered vehicles. They have the same rights on the roadways as motor vehicles and they must obey the rules of the road like any other vehicle.

Motorists should leave at least three feet when passing bicycles, more room at higher speeds.  They should change lanes to pass any bicycle traveling, if possible.

Motorists should look for bicycles in the opposing lane to them before they turn left.  The most common cause of bicycle crashes is a motorist making a left turn across the path of an oncoming bicycle.

Motorists should scan sidewalks and crosswalks for pedestrians and bicyclists.  They must yield to pedestrians who have started crossing at an intersection or crosswalk. 

Motorists must also yield to pedestrians who have started crossing a roadway, within a marked or an unmarked crosswalk, at an intersection not controlled by traffic signals.

Motorists should always look for bicyclists and pedestrians to their right side before they leave a stop light or stop sign. They should also look to the left and right side sidewalks when they are on a one-way street.

Pedestrians should not suddenly move into the path of a closely approaching vehicle that does not have sufficient time to yield for them.

The Madison Police Department needs your help to make our roads safer for EVERYONE.  Distracted driving, walking or biking can cause grave danger to you and anyone else on the road.  Please obey all traffic laws, focus on the road, be aware of others and pay attention to your surroundings and potential dangers when you are driving, biking or walking.

Increased Traffic Enforcement in July

In July, the Madison Police Department, in partnership with the Dane County Sheriff's Office, will be conducting extra patrols that will focus on enforcing Wisconsin's speeding, alcohol and seatbelt laws.  These additional enforcement efforts are made possible through traffic overtime grants provided by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation. The goal of these extra patrols is not only to enhance public safety, but to prevent needless tragedies. 

Speeding is a leading cause of death and injuries on Wisconsin roadways. And, someone is injured or killed in an impaired driving crash every two hours in Wisconsin and thousands of unbuckled passenger vehicle occupants are killed every year in crashes throughout the United States.

The Madison Police Department needs your help to make our roads safer.  Please put your cell phone down, buckle up, slow down and drive sober.

Officers arrived to find he had barricaded himself inside the home. While forming a contact team to safely remove him, the man ran out of a side door.

A K-9 team spotted the suspect running and followed him. The man refused requests to stop. He then jumped on a nearby pickup truck and attempted to climb onto the roof of an apartment building.

The suspect was once again directed to stop. He did not comply and K-9 Bowie was deployed onto the truck bed. The suspect began punching and assaulting Bowie during this time, still while ignoring commands to stop and get to the ground.

Other less lethal methods were used to stop the man from fleeing. He eventually complied with these orders and was taken into custody.

Due to a K9 being deployed, the suspect was taken to the hospital for a med clear before the Dane County Jail.

Gilbert J. Richards, 41, of Madison, was arrested by MPD for shoving and kicking police animals, criminal damage to property, resisting arrest and a parole violation. He was also booked into the jail on charges from another law enforcement agency.

K9 Bowie suffered a minor injury but is expected to be OK.

Increased Traffic Enforcement

In August, the Madison Police Department, in partnership with the Dane County Sheriff's Office, will be conducting extra patrols that will focus on enforcing Wisconsin's speeding, alcohol and seatbelt laws.  These additional enforcement efforts are made possible through traffic overtime grants provided by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation. The goal of these extra patrols is not only to enhance public safety, but to prevent needless tragedies. 

Speeding is a leading cause of death and injuries on Wisconsin roadways. And, someone is injured or killed in an impaired driving crash every two hours in Wisconsin and thousands of unbuckled passenger vehicle occupants are killed every year in crashes throughout the United States.

The Madison Police Department needs your help to make our roads safer.  Please put your cell phone down, buckle up, slow down and drive sober.

The Madison Police Department to Participate in a State-Funded Bicycle and Pedestrian Safety Grant from June 2023 to August 2023
 
This summer, the Madison Police Department will be conducting extra patrols that will focus on enforcing Wisconsin’s bicycle and pedestrian laws.  These additional enforcement efforts are made possible through traffic overtime grants provided by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation.

The goal of these extra patrols is not only to enhance public safety, but to also educate citizens and to prevent needless tragedies. Throughout the past five years in Wisconsin, there have been 10,737 pedestrians and bicyclists crashes, resulting in 9799 injuries and 336 deaths.  In 2022 alone, 1,378 pedestrians and 679 bicyclists in Wisconsin were involved in motor vehicle crashes, resulting in 74 and 14 deaths, respectively. 

Bicycles, according to WI Statute, are considered vehicles. They have the same rights on the roadways as motor vehicles and they must obey the rules of the road like any other vehicle.
  • Motorists should leave at least three feet when passing bicycles, more room at higher speeds.  They should change lanes to pass any bicycle traveling, if possible.
  • Motorists should look for bicycles in the opposing lane to them before they turn left.  The most common cause of bicycle crashes is a motorist making a left turn across the path of an oncoming bicycle.
  • Motorists should scan sidewalks and crosswalks for pedestrians and bicyclists.  They must yield to pedestrians who have started crossing at an intersection or crosswalk. 
  • Motorists must also yield to pedestrians who have started crossing a roadway, within a marked or an unmarked crosswalk, at an intersection not controlled by traffic signals.
  • Motorists should always look for bicyclists and pedestrians to their right side before they leave a stop light or stop sign. They should also look to the left and right side sidewalks when they are on a one-way street.
  • Pedestrians should not suddenly move into the path of a closely approaching vehicle that does not have sufficient time to yield for them.
The Madison Police Department needs your help to make our roads safer for EVERYONE.  Distracted driving, walking or biking can cause grave danger to you and anyone else on the road.  Please obey all traffic laws, focus on the road, be aware of others and pay attention to your surroundings and potential dangers when you are driving, biking or walking.

Drive Sober or Get Pulled Over
Enforcement Campaign Begins

During the weeks leading up to, and including, the Labor Day holiday, the U.S. Department of Transportation’s National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) will be working alongside law enforcement agencies across the country to decrease impaired driving.  The goal is to save lives during what is usually a dangerous holiday on our nation’s roads.
 
From August 18 through September 4, the Madison Police Department will be participating in the Drive Sober or Get Pulled Over high-visibility enforcement period. In support of the law enforcement community’s dedication to protecting the lives of residents in their communities, you’ll see officers working hard to take impaired drivers off the roads. As you head out to festivities during the end of summer and Labor Day weekend, remember: Drive Sober or Get Pulled Over.  No matter how you plan to celebrate the end of summer this year, make sure you plan to do it safely.
 
  • Always drive 100% sober. Even one alcoholic beverage could be one too many.  
  • Plan ahead: Before you have even one drink, designate a sober driver to get you home safely.
  • You have options to get home safely: designate a sober driver or call a taxi or rideshare. Getting home safely is always worth it.
  • If it’s your turn to be the designated driver, take your job seriously and don’t drink.
  • If you have a friend who is about to drink and drive, take the keys away and let a sober driver get your friend home safely.

The Madison Police Department is investigating after a woman was brutally attacked early Sunday morning downtown.

The woman was found along the 500 block of W. Wilson St. around 3:20 a.m. A person living in the area called for police after noticing the victim was severely beaten.

The victim was rushed to the hospital with life-threatening injuries. She remains in critical condition as of Sunday afternoon.

She is a student at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. We are working with University leaders to connect her friends and family with any support or resources they may need.

This appears to be a stranger assault. No arrests have been made at this time.

“I have authorized a full complement of police resources to bring this person or persons to justice,” Madison Police Chief Shon Barnes said during a media briefing on Sunday.
 
Detectives and investigators are swabbing the area for biological evidence and recanvassing the area on Sunday.

They are also searching for additional witnesses and surveillance video. Detectives are specifically looking for video from people who live within a few blocks of the W. Wilson and Bedford St. intersection and have video from 2-4am.

Video and information can be shared by contacting  the Madison Police Department’s non-emergency line at 608-255-2345 or Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014. Information can also be shared anonymously through Crime Stoppers at p3tips.com.
 
“This investigation is in its preliminary stages right now. We have called in numerous Madison Police personnel on this holiday weekend to conduct a thorough and complete investigation,” said Assistant Chief Paige Valenta, who oversees the department’s investigative units.
 
Patrols in this area will be increased in the area for the time being. Residents are encouraged not to walk alone in the area, particularly at night. People are also encouraged be aware of their surroundings and to notify someone of their departures and arrivals if walking alone the in the area.

This remains an active investigation.
