Four officers were treated at a local hospital for minor injuries consisting of abrasions, bruises and a facial laceration.  Even after chemical sedation at the hospital, the suspect was resistive and required extra officers to assist with the transport.  

The subject, now identified as 30 year old Tyrone Underwood, has been booked into the Dane County Jail and is facing numerous charges including Resisting Causing Injury and Disorderly Conduct.  It has now been discovered that Underwood was also being sought by officers in another district for charges on an unrelated matter, and as he is currently out on bail for another recent case, he is also facing Bail Jumping charges.  

Officers believe Underwood was under the influence of illegal drugs, which likely contributed to his erratic behavior and allowed him to resist the efforts of numerous officers to take him into custody.

The City of Madison is under Thunderstorm watch until Saturday night (6/21/2024) at 7pm. During this time, we are expecting severe winds, hail, significant rain and possible tornadoes. In terms of staying safe during the storms, the Madison Police Department wants individuals to remember:
  • Turn Around, Don’t Drown-Avoid driving or walking on roads that are flooded.
  • Have a Severe Weather Plan:
    • Monitor weather forecasts and traffic updates.
    • Have a plan with your family and a place to meet on higher ground if you experience substantial flooding.
    • Identify a safe route to exit your home and neighborhood if there is significant flooding.
    • Make sure your home is prepared for flooding. Ensure you have a working sump pump, Keep important documents in an elevated waterproof container. 
Also, be sure to monitor the City of Madison website for additional information and updates this weekend.

MPD Officers were dispatched to a series of Armed Robbery reports in the Sherman/Northport area.  A total of 6 victims were contacted indicating that a male suspect had threatened them with gun violence while demanding money.  Victims in the Lakeview Library were forced to turn over money from the library.  An officer spotted Lucas, who fit the suspect description provided by the victims, emerging from behind a dumpster.  After Lucas was contacted, he made incriminating statements, was found to have evidence on his person that tied him to the crime, and was identified as the suspect.  He was lodged at the Dane County Jail on charges of Armed Robbery.  Lucas was found to be out on bail for three previous Armed Robbery cases earlier this year, and charges of Felony Bail Jumping were added.

On June 23, 2024, Madison Police conducted an enforcement operation in the area of the East Towne Mall in response to an unsanctioned racing-related event that was scheduled to take place there.  The event, referred to as “Madison Takeover 2024,” was slated to take place after the mall closed, with invitations circulating on social media.  

Street racing and the resulting reckless driving behavior has been a top concern for the Madison Police Department as it has been associated with a number of fatalities on local roadways.  The racing activity has also been linked to disturbances, drug use, and significant property damage.  East Towne Mall management has reported hundreds of thousands of dollars in property damage in the last few months, mainly to paved surfaces, as a result of car racing and burnouts on the premises.  

During tonight’s enforcement operation, members of the Community Policing Team, along with other officers, issued over 80 citations in the East Towne Mall and E. Washington Ave corridor.  Most of the citations were for trespassing, but citations were also issued for speeding and reckless driving as well.

MPD Officers are responding to a traffic incident in the 1900 block of Moorland Road.

Vehicular traffic will be shut down off of South Towne Road to this area and motorists are asked to take alternative routes to avoid these roadways until the roadway is re-opened.  



MPD personnel investigated a motor vehicle accident between a motorcycle and another motor vehicle.  The incident resulted in one deceased person.  Traffic Investigators processed the scene and traffic is now opened.

A person was crossing E Washington Ave when they were struck by what was reported to be a dark colored sedan. The victim, a 40yo male, was taken to a local hospital where they were treated for non-life threatening injuries. The suspect vehicle fled the scene and was not located. A small stretch of E Washington Ave was closed temporarily for investigative purposes.

Madison police responded to the 200 block of State Street early Sunday morning after two workers at Paul’s Club were battered by an unruly patron.
 
The subject was reportedly trying to start fights with others in the business and when employees approached to ask the subject to leave, the subject turned his anger on staff.
 
Staff sustained minor injuries and the subject was arrested a short time later by police.
 
Michael Hommerding, 29, was arrested for 2 counts of simple battery.

The Madison Police Department responded to a disturbance in the city’s central district Saturday evening.
 
Officers were dispatched to a multi-unit building located along the 300 block of Dayton Street around 10:20 PM.
 
A caller told dispatch she needed help, and the dispatcher could hear a male in the background telling her to hangup. The caller also stated the people in the apartment had guns and threatened to harm the caller for calling the police.
 
Once on scene, officers learned there were no guns and were able to make contact with several individuals inside the apartment.
 
Dontel Coney, 41, was arrest for disorderly conduct and taken to the Dane County Jail.

The Madison Police Department responded to a domestic disturbance on the city’s west side Saturday evening.
 
Officers were dispatched to a hotel in the 8100 block of Excelsior Drive when hotel management called after a guest reported hearing a disturbance and witnessing a man dragging a female down the hall and into a room.
 
Officers were able to make contact with both subjects and learned the victim was battered and held against her will by another subject in the room.
 
Nashawn Davis, 23, was arrested on charges of domestic battery, disorderly conduct, suffocation, and false imprisonment.

Madison police are responding to the area of S Stoughton Rd and Milwaukee St for a reported vehicle accident.
 
Callers reported that a black sports car was speeding before it crashed and exited the roadway. The vehicle crashed into some trees where it became fully engulfed in flames. Police officers were able to extricate 1 person from the car and that person is being transported to the hospital.
 
The investigation into the crash is ongoing and police are requesting people avoid the area until further notice.

Madison police responded to the 200 block of E Olin Ave on the city’s south side after callers reported seeing a subject slumped over the wheel of a vehicle.
 
Upon arrival they made contact with a subject who showed signs of intoxication and admitted to alcohol and other drug usage. The subject refused to participate in standardized field sobriety testing and was transported to the hospital for a blood draw.
 
Whitney Jackson, 37, was arrested for 2nd offense OWI and transported to the Dane County Jail.

At 12:46 PM Madison police responded to the 500 block of Northport Dr for a reported disturbance.

Officers were able to remove everyone from the apartment safely and detain the primary suspect. There is no report of injuries and there is no threat to the public.
 
The investigation is on going at this time.

Madison Officers were dispatched to the 2900 block of Traceway Dr for a report of 10-20 kids and their parents fighting.
 
Both sides of the dispute were throwing rocks at one another, posturing to fight and a gun was mentioned to have been involved as well.
 
Officers were able to make contact with several subjects involved before all parties dispersed. No gun was located.
 
Deandray Smith, 32, was arrested for disorderly conduct.

Address: N. Orchard St. and Regent St/
Details:
Madison officers responded to the intersection of N Orchard St and Regent St Monday evening for a car vs. motorcycle accident.
 
Initial investigation reveled that the motorcyclist was hit by the car as the car was turning left onto Regent St and then partially pinned under it.
 
The motorcyclist was transported to a local hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.
 
At this time, it does not appear that drugs or alcohol were a factor in this crash.

Address: S Whitney Way and Research Park Blvd
Details:
Bystanders attempted life saving measures on a subject located down at S Whiteny Way and Research Park Blvd Monday afternoon.
 
Officers responded to the area after dispatchers advised there was multiple people calling in stating bystanders were performing CPR on a subject down at the above intersection.
 
Officers arrived on scene with Madison Fire and life saving efforts continued. The subject later passed away at the hospital.

Address: Mineral Point Rd and W Gammon Rd

Details:
Officers responded to the 1100 block of Morraine View Dr on the city’s West side Tuesday afternoon for a domestic disturbance involving a knife.
 
Initial information was that the victim and her children were unable to leave the apartment due to the suspect possessing a knife and not allowing them to leave.
 
As officers arrived, the victim and children were able to leave and meet officers. The victim suffered minor injuries and there were no physical injures to the children.
 
Aaron Mixon, 23, was arrested for domestic battery, disorderly conduct and felony bail jumping.

Madison Officer’s responded to the 50 block of Northridge Terrace after a caller reported hearing about 15 shots fired and arguing.
 
Officers responded to the area and located 6 shell casings and 1 unfired bullet near a parking lot. Two vehicles were struck by gunfire and were unoccupied. One of the vehicles was also a stolen auto.
 
No reports of injuries at this time. Investigation is ongoing.

Tuesday evening officers responded to the 2900 block of Traceway Dr for subjects who had been sprayed by OC.
 
Upon arrival officers are able to make contact with the victims who reported that they had been battered earlier in the day by the same suspect and then while they were in their vehicle, the suspect approached and sprayed them with OC.
 
One victim was 3 months pregnant and was punched in the face by the suspect as well.
 
Officers arrested multiple subjects involved in this incident, which is a continuation from the incident that occurred in the same area on 6/24/2024.

The Madison Police Department’s Traffic Enforcement Team along with officers working a state funded grant joined forces to stop speeding cars near a pedestrian heavy crosswalk and school zone.
 
Officers stopped 26 cars, with a low speed of 50 and a high speed of 54. For context, the speed limit is 35 mph in the zone they were monitoring.
 
Great work done by all in assisting with the safety of pedestrians using this crosswalk along with working to slow speeders down!

The Madison Mallards will be having their annual fireworks show at Warner Park on Wednesday, July 3rd. 

Fireworks will start around 9:45 p.m.  The show will last approximately 20 minutes. 

Traffic after the fireworks, especially in the North District, will be heavy in volume.  While we have a great plan to get the cars moving out of the area as quickly as possible, citizens driving or riding a bus should expect some delays for about 30-45 minutes after the fireworks end. 

The Madison Police Department thanks you in advance for your patience.

Address: East Washington Ave / N. First St
Details:
On the night of June 28, 2024, Madison Police officers were engaged in a pro-active OWI enforcement operation in the East Washington Avenue corridor.  

Around 11:18PM, officers observed a vehicle that had managed to get stuck on the railroad tracks that intersect with East Washington Avenue, after apparently driving a short distance on them as if they were a roadway.  Officers contacted the confused motorist, who appeared intoxicated and advised they were simply following directions from their GPS navigation device.  

The driver was eventually arrested for 2nd Offense OMVWI and was found to have a BAC of .18, more than twice the legal limit.

A woman attempted to punch an employee when she was asked to leave a downtown bar Sunday night.

Employees said the woman was disruptive and shouted at customers while intoxicated. 

Initially they were able to get the woman to leave without issue, but she returned a short while later.

Staff began to escort her out a second time when she tried to punch an employee.

Officers were dispatched to the bar, located along the 110 block of W. Main Street, around 9:15.

As they arrived, the woman returned to the area for a third time.

Kylie K. Swenson, 31, was arrested for disorderly conduct, attempted battery and resisting arrest.

A man threated to harm a dog after it barked at him Sunday night.

The dog was being walked on the sidewalk near McKenna Blvd.

Its owner moved over as the man passed by, but the dog barked and the man began shouting.

A stranger driving by noticed the man’s behavior and called 911.

The man was located nearby and taken into custody for disorderly conduct a probation violation.

Officers responded after a woman was found slumped over the wheel of her vehicle parked in the middle of the road.

Officers were dispatched to the intersection Agriculture and Dairy Drives around 5:45 a.m. on Sunday.

The woman admitted to drinking and driving. Open containers of alcohol were also found inside the vehicle.

Kathryn A. Kelly, 58, of Madison, was arrested for fourth-offense OWI.

There was damage to the  vehicle, but officers were unable to locate a crash scene.

Address: Westbound Hwy 30 at E. Washington Ave.
Details:
A gun was found in a vehicle following a crash involving an intoxicated driver.

Officers were dispatched to Highway 30 at E. Washington Ave. around 3 p.m. on Saturday for a crash.

The driver was out of the vehicle and showed signs of being intoxicated.

Open containers of alcohol were also found in the vehicle.

The 21-year-old man from Iowa was ultimately arrested for first-offense OWI, carrying a concealed weapon and endangering safety by going armed with a firearm while under the influence of an intoxicant.

The man was taken to the Dane County Jail after being medically cleared.

A large crowd formed as two teens began to physically fight with one another Saturday afternoon.

Officers were dispatched to the 300 block of W. Olin Ave. Multiple people called 911 to report the disturbance. 

As officers arrived, they attempted to detain the 13-year-old and 15-year-old girls involved in the fight.

As they did this, a 13-year-old boy intervenes and tries to fight officers.

The 13-year-old and 15-year-old girls were charged with disorderly conduct and resisting.

The 13-year-old boy was charged with resisting.

All were taken to the Juvenile Reception Center.

An officer was proactively trying to stop speeders on the Beltline on Saturday morning.

By 8 a.m., he had made four traffic stops for 91 mph, 90 mph, 90 mph and 87 mph.

One driver, when asked if he knew why he was stopped, responded with “I was going crazy fast.”

All drivers were compliant and cited.

A man attempted to get into vehicles and yelled at customers outside of McDonalds restaurant on Friday.
 
Officers were dispatched to the location along the 1100 block of Regent Street around 9:30 p.m.

As the man was  being detained, threatened an officer.
Larry E. Smith, 41, was arrested for disorderly conduct, threats to law enforcement and two counts of bail jumping.

Multiple people requested police after seeing a group of kids fighting in the street.

Officers were dispatched to the 2400 block of Lafollette Ave. around 11:25 a.m.

No fighting was taking place when officers arrived.

The incident remains under investigation.

Shortly before 9:00PM, officers were dispatched to a fight near State Street and W. Mifflin Street, allegedly involving a knife.  According to one of the reporting parties, a female involved in the fight was bleeding profusely.   Officers arrived to find a female victim with significant lacerations from an edged weapon.  While some officers rendered aid to the victim, others searched for the suspect, who fled prior to their arrival.  The victim was transported to an area hospital where her condition was stabilized.  

A pruning saw was located nearby and determined to be the weapon used by the suspect in the altercation.  Officers believe that the victim and suspect knew each other, and the attack with the saw was the result of a disagreement between the two.  

Officers are still looking for the suspect, identified as Alicia Padilla, who will face felony charges of 1st Degree Reckless Injury and Substantial Battery, as well Disorderly Conduct while armed and Bail Jumping.  Padilla is also wanted on a probation warrant through the Wisconsin Department of Corrections.  If you have information about Padilla’s whereabouts, call Madison Area Crimestoppers at 608-266-6014.

MPD officers are assisting our partners at MFD with traffic control on a fire incident in this block.  Traffic will be closed on Vondron Road from Mustang Way to Agriculture Drive until further notice.  Please use alternate routes of transportation.

Address: N Stoughton Rd. at State Hwy 30
Details: East officers were dispatched along with Dane County units to assist with a semi-truck flipped onto its side at N. Stoughton Rd. at State Hwy 30. Officers quickly formulated a traffic plan to help ease the back up. The Madison Fire Department got on scene quickly to assist the driver with a minor injury, he was not transported by EMS. This is a single vehicle traffic incident with the truck was turning from southbound Hwy 51 to outbound Hwy 30 when their load potentially shifted causing the truck to tip over. The truck’s load consists of shredded metal. Traffic can still get through outbound Hwy 30 but the flow of traffic is down to one lane – expect delays and avoid the area if possible as it may take several hours to unload the truck, tip it back upright and reload it. The Wisconsin State Patrol has sent inspectors to assist in the investigation.

The Madison Police Department is investigating a fatality crash on the northside near the intersection of Packers Ave. and Tennyson Lane. There are two people in custody related to the crash. This is an active investigation. The Madison Police Department wishes to thank the Dane County Sheriff's Office, the University of Wisconsin- Madison Police Department, the Maple Bluff Police Department, the Fitchburg Police Department and the Sun Prairie Police Department who assisted and continue to support this investigation.

Officers of the Madison Police Department and the MPD SWAT Team assisted the Columbus Police Department and Division of Criminal Investigation in the apprehension of a homicide suspect at this hotel.  The suspect was safely detained; and care and custody of him was turned over to the the CPD for further invesgitation.

On July 4th at about 9:21 PM, officers responded to a report of a fight at Elver Park at 1250 McKenna Blvd. Upon arrival, they encountered about 500 people in the park, lighting off fireworks in various locations. 
As officers and park rangers attempted to announce the closure of the park and maintain order, there were numerous instances of individuals lighting off fireworks at them.  Several people were nearly struck, but ultimately nobody was injured. Fire rescue responded to put out small fires and douse remaining fireworks. Officers directed traffic in order to assist the large amount of vehicles leaving the park. This incident was able to be resolved safely and with no arrests.

Dorothea Murphy is an 87 year old woman who has recently been suffering from dementia issues. Tonight, family members woke up around 3:00 AM to find the front door open and Dorothea missing. She is about 5'2", thin build, with short, white hair. Dorothea was last seen wearing jeans and a blue short sleeved t-shirt. If located, contact MPD dispatch.
